title: How to Get a Pear Into a Wine Bottle

steps.headline: Select bottles and clean thoroughly.
Wrap a piece of nylon cord around the bottle about 1/3 way up from bottom.
Pull the ends until they are equal in length.
Secure temporarily with scotch tape
Attach cord to bottle with a small amount of e-6000 or good quality silicone adhesive, placed as small globs in 3 different spots.
Place bottles where the glue may dry

In the spring, after the pear tree has blossomed, the blossoms have fallen off, and the fruit bud is visible, select a bud that is at or near the end of a branch that is thin enough to fit into the opening in the bottle.
Prune any extra foliage along the branch enough so you can push the bud and about 6-8" of the branch into the bottle.
Carefully insert the bud into the bottle.
steps.description: Use hanger wire to snugly wrap around the neck of the bottle and last part of the base of the bottle. connect the two wrapped end with the wire so that it does not slip. This would be fail-proof hanging strap for the bottle on to a branch of the tree.

steps.headline: Secure the branch into the bottle using green florist tape, by wrapping the tape around the bottle neck and working toward the branch.
Continue wrapping the branch and bottle neck until a good firm connection is made.
Secure the bottle by tying the strings to a branch above the bottle.
Position the bottle bottom so that it is slightly higher than the neck.
steps.description: This keeps rain from getting into the bottle.

steps.headline: Every few days throughout the season check on the bottle and rotate occasionally.
Reposition the bottle occasionally to allow the fruit to grow and minimize the amount of time the fruit touches the bottle in one spot.
When the fruit is ripe, cut the stem and strings and remove the bottle from the tree.
Remove the string and scrape off the silicone or adhesive off the bottle.
steps.description: Unwrap the florist tape and carefully pull the branch out of the bottle until the fruit hits the neck. Gently twist and pull on branch until fruit comes loose.

steps.headline: You could also fashion a small hook on the end of a piece of coat hanger to assist the removal of the branch.
Pour water containing vegetable wash into bottle and swish gently.
Do this a couple of times an rinse with clean cool tap water.
Bottle is now ready for you to add favorite beverage cap and enjoy.

tyn: E-6000 glue (available at craft stores) or silicone caulk
Nylon string cut into 3 foot (0.9 m) lengths
text: Select bottles and clean thoroughly.  Wrap a piece of nylon cord around the bottle about 1/3 way up from bottom.  Pull the ends until they are equal in length.  Secure temporarily with scotch tape  Attach cord to bottle with a small amount of e-6000 or good quality silicone adhesive, placed as small globs in 3 different spots.  Place bottles where the glue may dry  In the spring, after the pear tree has blossomed, the blossoms have fallen off, and the fruit bud is visible, select a bud that is at or near the end of a branch that is thin enough to fit into the opening in the bottle.  Prune any extra foliage along the branch enough so you can push the bud and about 6-8" of the branch into the bottle.  Carefully insert the bud into the bottle. Use hanger wire to snugly wrap around the neck of the bottle and last part of the base of the bottle. connect the two wrapped end with the wire so that it does not slip. This would be fail-proof hanging strap for the bottle on to a branch of the tree. Secure the branch into the bottle using green florist tape, by wrapping the tape around the bottle neck and working toward the branch.  Continue wrapping the branch and bottle neck until a good firm connection is made.  Secure the bottle by tying the strings to a branch above the bottle.  Position the bottle bottom so that it is slightly higher than the neck. This keeps rain from getting into the bottle. Every few days throughout the season check on the bottle and rotate occasionally.  Reposition the bottle occasionally to allow the fruit to grow and minimize the amount of time the fruit touches the bottle in one spot.  When the fruit is ripe, cut the stem and strings and remove the bottle from the tree.  Remove the string and scrape off the silicone or adhesive off the bottle. Unwrap the florist tape and carefully pull the branch out of the bottle until the fruit hits the neck. Gently twist and pull on branch until fruit comes loose. You could also fashion a small hook on the end of a piece of coat hanger to assist the removal of the branch.  Pour water containing vegetable wash into bottle and swish gently.  Do this a couple of times an rinse with clean cool tap water.  Bottle is now ready for you to add favorite beverage cap and enjoy.
sentences: Select bottles and clean thoroughly.
Wrap a piece of nylon cord around the bottle about 1/3 way up from bottom.
Pull the ends until they are equal in length.
Secure temporarily with scotch tape  Attach cord to bottle with a small amount of e-6000 or good quality silicone adhesive, placed as small globs in 3 different spots.

Place bottles where the glue may dry  In the spring, after the pear tree has blossomed, the blossoms have fallen off, and the fruit bud is visible, select a bud that is at or near the end of a branch that is thin enough to fit into the opening in the bottle.
Prune any extra foliage along the branch enough so you can push the bud and about 6-8" of the branch into the bottle.
Carefully insert the bud into the bottle.
Use hanger wire to snugly wrap around the neck of the bottle and last part of the base of the bottle.
connect the two wrapped end with the wire so that it does not slip.
This would be fail-proof hanging strap for the bottle on to a branch of the tree.
Secure the branch into the bottle using green florist tape, by wrapping the tape around the bottle neck and working toward the branch.
Continue wrapping the branch and bottle neck until a good firm connection is made.
Secure the bottle by tying the strings to a branch above the bottle.
Position the bottle bottom so that it is slightly higher than the neck.
This keeps rain from getting into the bottle.
Every few days throughout the season check on the bottle and rotate occasionally.
Reposition the bottle occasionally to allow the fruit to grow and minimize the amount of time the fruit touches the bottle in one spot.
When the fruit is ripe, cut the stem and strings and remove the bottle from the tree.
Remove the string and scrape off the silicone or adhesive off the bottle.
Unwrap the florist tape and carefully pull the branch out of the bottle until the fruit hits the neck.
Gently twist and pull on branch until fruit comes loose.
You could also fashion a small hook on the end of a piece of coat hanger to assist the removal of the branch.
Pour water containing vegetable wash into bottle and swish gently.
Do this a couple of times an rinse with clean cool tap water.
Bottle is now ready for you to add favorite beverage cap and enjoy.
